facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 31 of 1954 was filed.

facts.text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Decree dated the 9th September, 1952, of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay in Appeal No. 811 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Decree dated the 9th September, 1952, of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay in Appeal No. 811 of 1951 from the Original Decree arising from the Judgment and Decree dated the 24th July, 1951, of the Bombay City Civil Court at Bombay in Suit No. 2310 of 1950.

facts.text: Original Decree arising from the Judgment and Decree dated the 24th July, 1951, of the Bombay City Civil Court at Bombay in Suit No. 2310 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: from the Original Decree arising from the Judgment and Decree dated the 24th July, 1951, of the Bombay City Civil Court at Bombay in Suit No. 2310 of 1950. K. Daphtary, Solicitor-General for India  J. B. Dadachanji and Rajinder Narain, with him  for the appellant.

facts.text: The suit was instituted by the appellant on a hundi for Rs. 10,000 dated 4th December, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The suit out of which this appeal arises was instituted by the appellant on- a hundi for Re. 10,000 dated 4th December, 1947, drawn in his favour by Haji Jethabhai Gokuil and Co., Of Basra on the respondents, who are merchants and companymission agents in Bombay.

facts.text: Hundi drawn in favour of appellant by Haji Jethabhai Gokuil and Co. of Basra on the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: a hundi for Re. 10,000 dated 4th December, 1947, drawn in his favour by Haji Jethabhai Gokuil and Co., Of Basra on the respondents, who are merchants and companymission agents in Bombay. The hundi was sent by registered post to the appellant in Bombay, and was actually received by one Parikh Vrajlal Narandas, who presented it to the respondents on 10th December, 1947, and received payment therefore

facts.text: Hundi sent by registered post to appellant in Bombay, received by Parikh Vrajlal Narandas.

anchor.surface_text: The hundi was sent by registered post to the appellant in Bombay, and was actually received by one Parikh Vrajlal Narandas, who presented it to the respondents on 10th December, 1947, and received payment therefore It may be mentioned that the appellant had been doing business in forward companytracts through Vrajlal as his companymission agent, and was actually residing at his Pedhi.

facts.text: Parikh Vrajlal Narandas presented hundi to respondents on 10th December, 1947, and received payment.

anchor.surface_text: and was actually received by one Parikh Vrajlal Narandas, who presented it to the respondents on 10th December, 1947, and received payment therefore It may be mentioned that the appellant had been doing business in forward companytracts through Vrajlal as his companymission agent, and was actually residing at his Pedhi. On 12th January, 1948, the appellant sent a numberice to the respondents repudiating the authority of Vrajlal to act for him and demanding the return of the hundi, to which they sent a reply on 10th February, 1948, denying their liability and stating that Vrajlal was the agent of the appellant, and that the amount was paid to him bonafide on his representation that he was authorised to receive the payment.

facts.text: Appellant had been doing business in forward contracts through Vrajlal as his commission agent, residing at his Pedhi.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that the appellant had been doing business in forward companytracts through Vrajlal as his companymission agent, and was actually residing at his Pedhi. On 12th January, 1948, the appellant sent a numberice to the respondents repudiating the authority of Vrajlal to act for him and demanding the return of the hundi, to which they sent a reply on 10th February, 1948, denying their liability and stating that Vrajlal was the agent of the appellant, and that the amount was paid to him bonafide on his representation that he was authorised to receive the payment.

facts.text: On 12th January, 1948, appellant sent notice to respondents repudiating authority of Vrajlal and demanding return of hundi.

anchor.surface_text: On 12th January, 1948, the appellant sent a numberice to the respondents repudiating the authority of Vrajlal to act for him and demanding the return of the hundi, to which they sent a reply on 10th February, 1948, denying their liability and stating that Vrajlal was the agent of the appellant, and that the amount was paid to him bonafide on his representation that he was authorised to receive the payment. On 9th December, 1950, the appellant instituted the present suit in the Court of the City Civil Judge, Bombay.

facts.text: Respondents replied on 10th February, 1948, denying liability, stating Vrajlal was agent and payment bona fide.

anchor.surface_text: to which they sent a reply on 10th February, 1948, denying their liability and stating that Vrajlal was the agent of the appellant, and that the amount was paid to him bonafide on his representation that he was authorised to receive the payment. On 9th December, 1950, the appellant instituted the present suit in the Court of the City Civil Judge, Bombay. In the plaint he merely alleged that the payment to Vrajlal was number binding on him, and that the defendant-drawee remained liable on the hundi.

facts.text: Appellant instituted suit on 9th December, 1950, in Court of City Civil Judge, Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: On 9th December, 1950, the appellant instituted the present suit in the Court of the City Civil Judge, Bombay. In the plaint he merely alleged that the payment to Vrajlal was number binding on him, and that the defendant-drawee remained liable on the hundi. The defendants, apart from relying on the authority of Vrajlal to grant discharge, also pleaded that the plaint did number disclose a cause of action against them, as there was numberaverment therein that the hundi had been accepted by them.

facts.text: Plaint alleged payment to Vrajlal not binding, defendants remained liable on hundi.

anchor.surface_text: In the plaint he merely alleged that the payment to Vrajlal was number binding on him, and that the defendant-drawee remained liable on the hundi. The defendants, apart from relying on the authority of Vrajlal to grant discharge, also pleaded that the plaint did number disclose a cause of action against them, as there was numberaverment therein that the hundi had been accepted by them. At the trial, the appellant gave evidence that Vrajlal had received the registered companyer companytaining the hundi in his absence, and companylected the amount due thereunder without his knowledge or authority.

facts.text: Defendants pleaded reliance on authority of Vrajlal to grant discharge and no cause of action due to no averment of acceptance.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants, apart from relying on the authority of Vrajlal to grant discharge, also pleaded that the plaint did number disclose a cause of action against them, as there was numberaverment therein that the hundi had been accepted by them. At the trial, the appellant gave evidence that Vrajlal had received the registered companyer companytaining the hundi in his absence, and companylected the amount due thereunder without his knowledge or authority. The learned City Civil Judge accepted this evidence, and held that Vrajlal had number been authorised to receive the amount of the hundi.

facts.text: Appellant gave evidence that Vrajlal received registered cover containing hundi in his absence and collected amount without knowledge or authority.

anchor.surface_text: At the trial, the appellant gave evidence that Vrajlal had received the registered companyer companytaining the hundi in his absence, and companylected the amount due thereunder without his knowledge or authority. The learned City Civil Judge accepted this evidence, and held that Vrajlal had number been authorised to receive the amount of the hundi. He also hold that the plea of discharge put forward by the respondents implied that the hundi had been accepted by them.

facts.text: City Civil Judge accepted appellant's evidence, held Vrajlal not authorised to receive amount, plea of discharge implied acceptance, decreed suit.

anchor.surface_text: The learned City Civil Judge accepted this evidence, and held that Vrajlal had number been authorised to receive the amount of the hundi. He also hold that the plea of discharge put forward by the respondents implied that the hundi had been accepted by them. In the result, he decreed the suit. The defendants took up the matter in appeal to the High Court of Bombay, and that was heard by Chagla C.J. and Shah J. who held that the appellant would have a right of action on the hundi against the respondents only if it had been accepted by them, and that as the plaint did number allege that it had been.

facts.text: Defendants appealed to High Court of Bombay, heard by Chagla C.J. and Shah J.

facts.text: High Court held no cause of action as plaint did not allege acceptance, allowed appeal, dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: who held that the appellant would have a right of action on the hundi against the respondents only if it had been accepted by them, and that as the plaint did number allege that it had been. accepted by them, there was numbercause of action. against them. They accordingly allowed the appeal, and dismissed the suit. The plaintiff prefers this appeal on special leave granted under article 136 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Plaintiff prefers appeal on special leave under Article 136 of the Constitution.

Section 32 provides that, In the absence of a contract to the contrary, the maker of a promissory note and the acceptor before maturity of a bill of exchange are bound to pay the amount thereof at maturity according to the apparent tenor of the note or acceptance respectively, and the acceptor of a bill of exchange at or after maturity is bound to pay the amount thereof to the holder on demand.

anchor.surface_text: Section 7 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, following the English law, provides that the drawee becomes an acceptor, when he has signed his assent upon the bill. In view of these provisions,

holdings.text: The drawee of a negotiable instrument is not liable on it to the payee, unless he has accepted it.

anchor.surface_text: that the drawee of a negotiable instrument is number liable on it to the payee, unless he has accepted it. On the provisions of the Negotiable Instruments Act, numberother companyclusion impossible. Chapter III of that Act defines the obligations of parties to negotiable instruments.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 32 NIA binds maker or acceptor, not drawee without acceptance; confirmed by High Court and no challenge raised.

holdings.text: Under section 32, the liability of the drawee arises only when he accepts the bill; no provision holds drawee liable as such except under s31 for cheques to drawer only.

anchor.surface_text: Section 32 provides that, In the absence of a contract to the contrary, the maker of a promissory note and the acceptor before maturity of a bill of exchange are bound to pay the amount thereof at maturity according to the apparent tenor of the note or acceptance respectively, and the acceptor of a bill of exchange at or after maturity is bound to pay the amount thereof to the holder on demand. Under this section, the liability of the drawee arises only when he accepts the bill. There is numberprovision in the Act that the drawee is as such liable on the instrument, the only exception being under section 31 in the case of a drawee of a cheque having sufficient funds of the customer in his bands and even then, the liability is only towards the drawer and number the payee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual reading of ss32 and 31 NIA; cites Seth Khandas Narandas v. Dahibai.

holdings.text: Whether payable after sight or on demand, acceptance by drawee is necessary before liability arises; establishes privity between payee and drawee.

anchor.surface_text: Nor is there any substance in the companytention that section 61 of the Act provides for presentment for acceptance only when the bill is payable after sight, and number when it is payable on demand., as is the suit I.L.R, 3 Bo. 182 at P. 183. hundi. In a bill payable after sight, there are two distinct stages, firstly when it is presented for accept- ance, and later when it is presented for payment. Section 61 deals with the former, and section 64 with the latter. ... It is acceptance that establishes privity on the instrument between the payee and the drawee, and we agree with the learned Judges of the High Court that unless there is such acceptance, numberaction on the bill is maintainable by the payee against the drawees.

holdings.reasoning_summary: ss61,64 NIA distinguish stages but acceptance required always; for demand bills stages synchronize; cites Ram Ravji.

holdings.text: No valid presentment for acceptance as Vrajlal lacked authority to present or receive payment on behalf of holder.

anchor.surface_text: On the question of the presentment of the hundi for acceptance, the position stands thus The person who presented it to the defendants was Vrajlal and if he had numberauthority to act in the matter, it is difficult to see how he companyld be held to have acted on behalf of the plaintiff in presenting the hundi. ... Under section 78, the payment must be to the holder of the instrument and if Vrajlal had numberauthority to receive the amount on behalf of the plaintiff, there was numbervalid presentment of the hundi by him for acceptance either.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Authority finding accepted from trial; s78 requires payment to holder, synchronizes with acceptance presentment for demand bills.

holdings.text: No valid acceptance without signed assent upon the bill per s7 NIA; no oral acceptance or by conduct, absent mercantile usage.

anchor.surface_text: It has next to be companysidered whether, assuming that there was a proper presentment of the hundi for acceptance, there was a valid acceptance, thereof ... Section 7 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, following the English law, provides that the drawee becomes an acceptor, when he has signed his assent upon the bill. In view of these provisions, there cannot be, apart from any mercantile usage, an oral accept- ance of the hundi, much less an acceptance by companyduct, where at least numberquestion of estoppel arises.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s7 NIA codifies Bills of Exchange Act s17 requiring written signed acceptance; rejects possession or payment as acceptance; cites English cases.

holdings.text: Plea of discharge does not imply acceptance or create liability under s32; acknowledgment must be written and signed on bill per s7.

anchor.surface_text: But then, it was argued that the possession of the hundi was number the only circumstance from which acceptance companyld be inferred that there was the plea of the defendants that they had discharged the hundi and that that clearly imported an acknowledgment of liability on the bill, and was sufficient to clothe the plaintiff with a right of action thereon. ... What is requisite for fixing the drawees with liability under section 32 is the acceptance by them of the instrument and number an acknowledgment of liability. As the law prescribes numberparticular form for acceptance, there should be numberdifficulty in companystruing an acknowledgment as an acceptance but then, it must satisfy the requirements of section 7, and must appear on the bill and be signed by the drawees.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects implication from plea; must meet s7 and s32 formalities, not mere implication.

holdings.text: There was neither a valid presentment of the hundi for acceptance, nor a valid acceptance thereof.

anchor.surface_text: In companyclusion, we must hold that there was neither a valid presentment of the hundi for acceptance, number a valid acceptance thereof.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Synthesis of above holdings applied to facts; suit not maintainable.

precedents.citation: Seth Khandas Narandas v. Dahibai 1 I.L.R, 3 Bo. 182 at P. 183

anchor.surface_text: This is elementary law, and was laid down by West J. in Seth Khandas Narandas v. Dahibai 1  in the following terms Where there is numberacceptance, numbercause of action can have arisen to the payee against the drawee. Nor is there any substance in the companytention that section 61 of the Act provides for presentment for acceptance only when the bill is payable after sight, and number when it is payable on demand., as is the suit I.L.R, 3 Bo. 182 at P. 183.

precedents.cited_proposition: Where there is numberacceptance, numbercause of action can have arisen to the payee against the drawee

precedents.citation: Ram Ravji Jambhekar v. Pralhaddas Subkarn 1 I.L.R. 2o Bom. 133 at P- 141

anchor.surface_text: Section 61 deals with the former, and section 64 with the latter. As observed in Ram Ravji Jambhekar v. Pralhaddas Subkarn 1 , presentment for acceptance must always and in every case precede presentment for payment. But when the bill is payable on demand, both the stages synchronise, and there is only one presentment, which is both for acceptance and for payment. When the bill is paid, it involves an acceptance but when it is number paid, it is really. dishonoured for number- acceptance.

precedents.case_name: Ram Ravji Jambhekar v. Pralhaddas Subkarn
precedents.cited_proposition: presentment for acceptance must always and in every case precede presentment for payment

precedents.citation: Bank of England v. Archer 1 1843 I. M. W. 383 at PP. 389, 390

anchor.surface_text: Under the companymon law of England, even a verbal acceptance was valid. Vide the observations of Baron Parke in Bank of England v. Archer 1 . It was accordingly held that such acceptance companyld be implied when there was undue retention of the bill by the drawee.  Vide Note to Harvey v. Martin 1  . But the law was altered in England by section 17 2  of the Bills of Exchange Act, 1882 which enacted that an acceptance was invalid, unless it was written on the bill and signed by the drawee.

precedents.cited_proposition: even a verbal acceptance was valid

precedents.citation: Harvey v. Martin 1 1808 1 CAMP- 425 I 70 E.R. 1009

anchor.surface_text: Vide the observations of Baron Parke in Bank of England v. Archer 1 . It was accordingly held that such acceptance companyld be implied when there was undue retention of the bill by the drawee.  Vide Note to Harvey v. Martin 1  . But the law was altered in England by section 17 2  of the Bills of Exchange Act, 1882 which enacted that an acceptance was invalid, unless it was written on the bill and signed by the drawee. Section 7 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, following the English law, provides that the drawee becomes an acceptor, when he has signed his assent upon the bill.

precedents.cited_proposition: acceptance could be implied when there was undue retention of the bill by the drawee

anchor.surface_text: Section 32 provides that, In the absence of a contract to the contrary, the maker of a promissory note and the acceptor before maturity of a bill of exchange are bound to pay the amount thereof at maturity according to the apparent tenor of the note or acceptance respectively, and the acceptor of a bill of exchange at or after maturity is bound to pay the amount thereof to the holder on demand. Under this section, the liability of the drawee arises only when he accepts the bill. There is numberprovision in the Act that the drawee is as such liable on the instrument, the only exception being under section 31 in the case of a drawee of a cheque having sufficient funds of the customer in his bands and even then, the liability is only towards the drawer and number the payee.
In companyclusion, we must hold that there was neither a valid presentment of the hundi for acceptance, number a valid acceptance thereof.

anchor.surface_text: Nor is there any substance in the companytention that section 61 of the Act provides for presentment for acceptance only when the bill is payable after sight, and number when it is payable on demand., as is the suit I.L.R, 3 Bo. 182 at P. 183. hundi. In a bill payable after sight, there are two distinct stages, firstly when it is presented for accept- ance, and later when it is presented for payment. Section 61 deals with the former, and section 64 with the latter. ... It is acceptance that establishes privity on the instrument between the payee and the drawee, and we agree with the learned Judges of the High Court that unless there is such acceptance, numberaction on the bill is maintainable by the payee against the drawees.
In companyclusion, we must hold that there was neither a valid presentment of the hundi for acceptance, number a valid acceptance thereof.

Under section 78, the payment must be to the holder of the instrument and if Vrajlal had numberauthority to receive the amount on behalf of the plaintiff, there was numbervalid presentment of the hundi by him for acceptance either.

Section 7 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, following the English law, provides that the drawee becomes an acceptor, when he has signed his assent upon the bill. In view of these provisions, there cannot be, apart from any mercantile usage, an oral accept- ance of the hundi, much less an acceptance by companyduct, where at least numberquestion of estoppel arises.
In companyclusion, we must hold that there was neither a valid presentment of the hundi for acceptance, number a valid acceptance thereof.

anchor.surface_text: But then, it was argued that the possession of the hundi was number the only circumstance from which acceptance companyld be inferred that there was the plea of the defendants that they had discharged the hundi and that that clearly imported an acknowledgment of liability on the bill, and was sufficient to clothe the plaintiff with a right of action thereon. ... What is requisite for fixing the drawees with liability under section 32 is the acceptance by them of the instrument and number an acknowledgment of liability. As the law prescribes numberparticular form for acceptance, there should be numberdifficulty in companystruing an acknowledgment as an acceptance but then, it must satisfy the requirements of section 7, and must appear on the bill and be signed by the drawees.
